sp.p: But since we cannot maintain her, nor she us, we must leave her.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 43.
div.stage: Enter Roger Trusty to his Lady all in a sweat with running: she seeing him come in such haste, cries out.

sp.speaker: HYpocondria.
sp.p: O help me, help me, you merciful Powers, to destroy me, and let me not outlive my Husband.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: 'Tis like the Gods will hear your prayers: for ten to one my Ma|ster out-lives you.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: VVhy, is he alive?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Yes, and alive's like.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: VVhat makes you sweat so?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: To bring you the good news of his well-being, and to prove the old Proverb a Lyar, which sayes, Bad Newes hath wings, and good Newes no legs.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Where did you meet your Master?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: In Westminster-Hall.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: How did he look?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Healthful and well.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Did he seem angry or pleas'd, merry or sad?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Why he neither seem'd angry nor pleas'd, merry nor sad, which I wonder'd at: for in Lawyers Courts, and places of Judicature, I never saw any face but was cloathed with a merry green countenance, or a sad black countenance, or a red cholerick face, or a pale malicious face; but my Masters face appeared like naked Truth, and clean Temperance, wash'd white with Innocency; being plump with health, and smooth with plenty.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: But why did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p:
VVhy he commanded me so to doe, and to run every step, to tell you he was comming home, and I chose as the wisest to run, al|though
I sweat for it, than stay and have a broken Head.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: VVell, I give you here a twenty-shilling-piece to dry your sweat with a cup of Sack.

div.stage: Exi Lady.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: May all my labours be rewarded thus.

sp.speaker: Maid Ioan.
sp.p: I perceive you take the gift as a due reward, and not as my Ladies bounty.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Hold your prating: what need we thank the Gods, if Saints me|rit Heaven?

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Sprightly, and the Lord VVidower her Father.

sp.speaker: LAdy Sprightly.
sp.p: Sir, I desire you would not think me undutiful to ask you a question: for I hope I am not so much in your disfavour, as not to re|solve me, since it is in your power.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: VVell, what is't that you would know?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: VVhether you are maried, or not?

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: VVhat if I am? Mariage is lawful.

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but I doubt whether it be honourable or not: for 'tis said you are maried to my Chamber-maid Dol Subtilty.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Perchance I am.

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Then I desire your Lordship will let me marry too.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: VVith all my heart, and I shall do my part towards thy mari|age; but to whom would you be maried?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Your Butler Sir.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Out upon thee base Girl, would you marry a Tapster?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Why Sir, a Tapster is as good as a piss-pot emptier; besides, they say you have done the fellow wrong: for she (they say) was his by pro|mise, and if Conscience hath right, he ought to have her; and perhaps, did not Ambition come in the way, Affection might prevail: wherefore to gra|tifie him, you ought in justice to bestow me upon him.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well, because you shall not marry my Butler, I will not marry your Maid: for the truth is, I never had so low a thought. But let me tell you, it is in the way of disobedience to question a Fathers Actions, and a presumption for a Child to think their Father is not wise enough to govern himself; besides, Children were ingrateful to Parents, to desire that from them, which they cannot, or will not keep to themselves, as neither to suffer a Father to marry, or keep a Mistress: Do Children think a Father is bound to so many Children, and no more?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Sir, I dare answer for the part of Children, that they would be well content that their Father should have Mistrisses, but they would be un|willing and griev'd that their Fathers should be their Mistrisses slave, where|by they incaptivate their Children, or ruine their Estates.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well then inquire no more after any Mistris I shall have, un|til you are incaptivated.
